intro: Misodendrum angulatum, commonly known as the angular mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on various host trees, primarily in the Mediterranean region. It has small, leathery leaves that are usually opposite and oval in shape. The plant produces small, white or greenish flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences. Its berries are typically red or yellow, containing seeds that are dispersed by birds. Botanically, it belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its unique morphology and parasitic growth habit.
